title: VC Daily: Question: How Could Inflation Affect VC?
text:
Liz Young, founder and CEO of real-estate advice startup Realm Living Inc., said that what ultimately caused Zillow's iBuying program to fail was that it is extremely risky to predict future home valuation in a volatile or quickly accelerating market. "This is where proptech startups must innovate," said Ms. Young.

This week's question: How could inflation affect venture capital? After U.S. inflation hit a three-decade high in October, what are the obvious as well as unexpected effects on the venture market?

Please email responses to yuliya.chernova@wsj.com.

And now on to the news...

Top News

New fund. True Wind Capital Management LP has raised $817 million for its second fund, slightly ahead of the $800 million target the private-equity firm launched by two former KKR & Co. technology deal makers set for it, WSJ Pro reports.

The San Francisco firm started fundraising before the coronavirus pandemic, paused for a while and then raised the bulk of the fund's capital in recent months. The fund attracted money from institutional investors like endowments and public pension plans, as well as from investors in Europe and Asia, according to Adam Clammer, True Wind's co-founder.

Mr. Clammer founded True Wind with Jamie Greene in 2015. They had spent years at KKR before launching the firm, which closed its $560 million debut fund in 2017. Most of the money for the debut fund came from family offices, Mr. Clammer said.

$122.99

Closing price of Rivian shares on Thursday, up from its initial-public-offering price of $78.00. (WSJ)

$76 Billion a Day: How Binance Became the World's Biggest Crypto Exchange

The world's fastest-growing major financial exchange has no head office or formal address, lacks licenses in countries where it operates and has a chief executive who until recently wouldn't answer questions about his location, WSJ reports. Started just four years ago, Binance is the exchange giant that towers over the digital currency world, a crypto equivalent of the London, New York and Hong Kong stock exchanges combined. After a burst of growth, Binance processes more trades for cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin and ether each day, $76 billion worth, than its four largest competitors put together, according to data provider CryptoCompare.

Companies Order Record Number of Robots Amid Labor Shortage

Robotics orders by North American companies are on track for their biggest year, according to an industry group, WSJ reports. Total robotics sales for the first nine months of the year were $1.48 billion, topping a previous record of $1.47 billion set over the same period in 2017, according to the Association for Advancing Automation, or A3. Sales rose from $1.09 billion in the first nine months of last year. A3's data look at industrial robots, which often are used for assembling parts or transporting heavy materials in production settings, according to the association.

Industry News

Funds

Digital Horizon raised $200 million for its second fund to continue investing in both early- and late-stage companies, focusing on fintech and software-as-a-service across Asia, Europe and Israel.

Canary aims to back roughly 50 Latin American startups from its new $100 million third fund. The firm secured $45 million in 2017 and $75 million in 2019 for its first and second funds, respectively.

People

Emergence Capital promoted Lotti Siniscalco to partner and Yaz El-Baba to senior associate. Before Emergence, Ms. Siniscalco was at Advent International, Ribbit Capital and NerdWallet. Mr. El-Baba joined the firm in 2019 from LinkedIn.

Costanoa Ventures named Amy Cheetham as the firm's newest partner. Prior to joining Costanoa two years ago, she was chief of staff, sales strategy and operations at Zuora.

Exits

Organon agreed to acquire fellow women's health provider Forendo Pharma for a total consideration of up to $954 million. Based in Finland, Forendo is backed by investors including Novo Seeds, Karolinska Development, Innovestor, Novartis Venture Fund, M Ventures and Sunstone Life Science Ventures.

Online food marketplace GrubMarket completed its acquisition of trucking and logistics provider Oakport Transportation for an undisclosed amount. San Francisco-based GrubMarket recently raised a $145 million Series E round from funds and accounts managed by BlackRock, Japan Post Capital, Walleye Capital, Celtic House Asia Partners, INP Capital, Pegasus Tech Ventures, Gaingels and others.

Cloud-security startup Lacework Inc. purchased Soluble, a cloud infrastructure management provider, for an undisclosed sum. San Jose, Calif.-based Lacework is backed by investors including Sutter Hill Ventures, Altimeter Capital, Liberty Global Ventures and Snowflake Ventures.

New Money

Cerebras Systems, a Sunnyvale, Calif.-based artificial-intelligence compute startup, raised $250 million in Series F funding, valuing the company at over $4 billion. Alpha Wave Ventures and Abu Dhabi Growth Fund led the round, which included contributions from Altimeter Capital, Benchmark Capital, Coatue Management, Eclipse Ventures, Moore Strategic Ventures and VY Capital.

Inspiration, a Washington, D.C.-based provider of electric-vehicle technology to fleet operators, secured a $200 million capital commitment from ArcLight Capital Partners' ArcLight Energy Partners Fund VII.

Density Inc., a San Francisco-based space-analytics platform for measuring building and workplace performance, secured $125 million in Series D funding led by Kleiner Perkins, valuing the company at just over $1 billion. New investors Altimeter Capital and Lachy Groom also participated in the round, along with previous backers including Upfront Ventures and Founders Fund.

Kodiak Robotics Inc., a Mountain View, Calif.-based self-driving trucking startup, secured $125 million in oversubscribed Series B financing from SIP Global Partners, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Battery Ventures, CRV, Muirwoods Ventures, Harpoon Ventures, StepStone Group, Gopher Asset Management, Walleye Capital, Aliya Capital Partners and others.

Zilch, a London-based buy now, pay later service, closed a $110 million Series C round led by Ventura Capital and Gauss Ventures at a valuation of more than $2 billion. With the new funding, the company plans to expand its presence in the U.S.

Acrivon Therapeutics Inc., an oncology therapeutics startup with offices in Watertown, Mass., and Sweden, picked up a $100 million oversubscribed Series B round. Wellington Management Co. and Surveyor Capital co-led the investment, which included additional support from RA Capital Management, Perceptive Advisors, Sands Capital, HBM Healthcare Investments, BB Pureos Bioventures, Acorn Bioventures and Alexandria Venture Investments. Derek DiRocco, partner at RA Capital, will join Acrivon's board.

ControlUp, a San Jose, Calif.-based startup that offers a digital employee-experience management platform, completed a $100 million funding round co-led by K1 Investment Management and JVP.

MFS Africa, a digital-payments network, collected $100 million in equity and debt funding. AfricInvest FIVE, Goodwell Investments and LUN Partners Group co-led the equity portion, which saw participation from CommerzVentures and Endeavor Catalyst. Lendable and Norsad provided the debt.

Wrapbook, a digital financial-services platform for the entertainment industry, landed $100 million in Series B funding. Tiger Global Management led the round, which included contributions from Andreessen Horowitz, WndrCo, Uncork Capital and Equal Ventures. The company has offices in Los Angeles, New York and Toronto.

Alt, an alternative asset trading platform, fetched $75 million in Series B funding from Spearhead, Seven Seven Six, Vibe Capital, Breyer Capital, Shrug Capital, Apollo Group, Hyperguap and others.

TriEye, a Tel Aviv-based provider of short-wave infrared sensing technology for mass-market applications, picked up a $74 million investment led by M&G Investments and Varana Capital. New investors including Samsung Ventures, Deep Insight and Discount Capital also supported the funding, alongside existing backers Intel Capital, Porsche Ventures and Grove Ventures.

Moov, a Tempe, Ariz.-based marketplace for used manufacturing equipment, closed a $41 million Series A round. Lead investor Tiger Global Management was joined by Atreides Management, Valor Equity Partners, Avenir Growth Fund and others.

Tech News

Justice Department sues Uber over charging wait-time fees for disabled people

Alibaba's ‘Singles Day' in China hit by global supply strains

How much do electric vehicles cost to ‘fill up' compared with buying gasoline?

Energy companies turn to 3-D printing to bypass snarled supply chains
